Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Electronics, Photonics and Magnetics (EPM) - Network for Computational Nanotechnology (NCN), To Be Held October 11-12, 2018, Alexandria,VA

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Workshop on Electronics, Photonics and Magnetics (EPM) - Network for Computational Nanotechnology (NCN) will be held on October 11-12 at the Holiday Inn, Alexandria, VA. It will allow to discuss issues related to development of computational tools to support the field of electronics, photonics and magnetics. The Workshop will host leading researchers in the field that will discuss the current state of the art, outline the pathways that allow efficient computation of nano/quantum devices, and propose, prioritize realistic research and development approaches that can lead to Computational Nanotechnology team efforts on Electronics, Photonics and Magnetics. There will be opportunities for information exchange and discussions on the development of computational tools to support the field as well as representing the community of users of these tools. Of major importance will be to determine possible ways a Node on Electronics, Photonics and Magnetics will allow efficient development of new tools and content dissemination worldwide via NSF's NCN Cyber Platform. Computation and simulation tools of this type will then be possible to be employed for turning nanoscale science and engineering into applications and impact future circuit and systems responding to grand challenges. There will be several plenary talks the will outline the state of the art in each area. Moreover, the plenary session will set the stage for the presentations and discussions in the breakout sessions that will be centered on the above mentioned four main themes. Each breakout session will feature several additional speakers that will focus on the details of specific topics related to the four different themes. A white paper will be prepared that outlines the current state of research, the opportunities and challenges, and the priority research and development directions. The Workshop is expected to play a key role in identifying new directions for research on novel electronic, photonic and magnetic devices for future systems. The white paper to be prepared will be made available to all interested parties and will allow better understanding of the modeling and computation field and its applications to a broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Workshop has focused on the way a Node on Electronics, Photonics and Magnetics will aid efficient development of new tools and content dissemination worldwide via NSF’s NCN Cyber Platform. A final report that has identified priority research and development directions has been prepared and disseminated.

Electronics

At present, compact model tools are available for for non-FINFET CMOS, SiGe and GaAs HBTs, GaN HEMTs poly–Si and a-Si TFTs. These tools need to evolve to be able to describe device operation and enable the design of compact models for FinFET CMOS and TeraFETs, and should include reliability indicators. Furthermore, compact models for flexible poly–Si and a-Si TFTs oxide TFTs should be developed as well. From the numerical standpoint, the above mentioned simulation approaches, Monte Carlo, DFT, hydrodynamic codes should be integrated with electromagnetic solvers. Ideally, one needs to have multiscale tools that are able to predict material and device operation in extreme conditions.

Thermal modeling at the nanoscale is emerging, but there are still conceptual and practical implementation challenges, for example heat transport across and in proximity to nanoscale interfaces, mixture of ballistic and diffusive phonon transport, non-bulk-like thermal behavior of materials when incorporated into nanoscale devices, coupling of heat between phonon transport in semiconductors and electron heat transport in metal interconnects. These issue are even more challenging in power electronics, especially with new materials.

A host of new materials are expected to be important for operation in extreme conditions. New theory, modelling and simulation approaches are needed. Bottom-up first-principles based methods that incorporate effect of thermodynamic potentials and external potentials will be essential for identifying materials/device behavior in extreme conditions. These methods needs to be able to predict the electronic properties evolution, the phase stability, defect concentration and role of device interfaces.

Photonics

The goal of a new established node should be to engineering a richer photonic phase-space, that is in phase, time, space should be a priority. The need to exploit a larger optical phase space has led to consider the following aspects:

Photonic structures with arbitrarily complex domains and local symmetries or lack of thereof, for example non-periodic or symmetry breaking, and hidden symmetries.

Engineered materials dispersion beyond regular dielectrics, for example ENZ media, metallic structures, and the engineering of space-time modulated materials and structure.

Resonant scattering phenomena in large-footprint devices with sub-wavelength features.

Modeling optical nonlinearity beyond perturbative theory.

The node should develop broad photonics roadmap beyond silicon photonics. The node should establish goal-driven initiative with industry involvement, similar to what SRC does. The node should organize workshop with industry participation to foster ideas, sponsorships and technology transfer.

Magnetics

A number of computational challenges were outline as relevant to the node on magnetics should address. Specifically, the development of computational platform to interface between different computer codes and simulation tools is considered a priority. With this the development of a number of standard problems to be used as benchmarks and to educate users. Furthermore, the development of open-access, open-source codes and to perform simulation and facilitate data sharing, possibly using a common data format. Another challenge is the development of user friendly interfaces to run a complex code, predict computational requirements, simply simulation workflow, and define simulation regime, may that be time and /or length scale for which code was developed. Due to its importance to understand fundamental properties of magnetic materials and devise, there is need to develop new theories and computational tools to include spin transport, quantum effects, and symmetries into account to simulate magnetization dynamics on the device level. Finally, new quantum-classical hybrid codes are needed to integrate classical micromagnetics with quantum transport of spin and charge

Infrastrucutres

The workshop participants have emphasized the availability of powerful community codes, either free to use of under some form of licensing, GNU or with limited fees. The development and use of “containers” such as Docker, Singularity, Reprosip and others. From the point of view of the hardware the emergence of Cloud Computing and the algorithmic speedups have exceeded hardware speedups.Furthermore, the following asopect have been considered important for the developem of a new node:

- The use web-services to enable simulation tools to discover available data streams that are going to be critical as data for input and for calibration and validation.

The use of simulations as a web service tool. Specifically these can lead to easy access of simulations from a data exploration tool. Powerful and easy to use calibration and validation tools. For example this could be done by making Sandia’s Dakota tool automatically available to a wider range of users.

The introduction of trusted source mechanism to verify the veracity of information being committed to data streams and databases.

Finally, the use of speculative computing to automatically augment the data infrastructure.
